title: Quiz 1: The Abdomen & GI Tract
description: Comprehensive review of the abdominal wall, peritoneum, GI tract (stomach to anal canal), liver, biliary system, pancreas, spleen, and kidneys.

questions.question: Which plane passes through the tip of the 9th costal cartilage, the pylorus, and the hila of the kidneys?
questions.explanation: The Transpyloric plane (of Addison) lies at the level of L1. It passes through the tips of the 9th costal cartilages, pylorus, pancreatic neck, duodenojejunal flexure, gall-bladder fundus, and kidney hila.
questions.hint: It is named after the stomach's exit.

questions.question: Match the abdominal artery with the embryonic gut section it supplies:
questions.explanation: Coeliac = Foregut (Oesophagus to D2). SMA = Midgut (D2 to distal transverse colon). IMA = Hindgut (Distal transverse colon to anal canal).
questions.hint: Think top-down: Stomach/Liver -> Small Intestine -> Colon/Rectum.

questions.question: Which of the following are contents of the Spermatic Cord? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The spermatic cord contains the vas deferens, testicular artery, pampiniform plexus, lymphatics, and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve. The ilioinguinal nerve runs IN the canal but OUTSIDE the cord.
questions.hint: Think about what the testis needs (blood in/out, sperm out, nerve supply).

questions.question: The inguinal ligament attaches laterally to the ___BLANK___ and medially to the ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The inguinal ligament (folded lower border of external oblique aponeurosis) runs from the ASIS to the pubic tubercle.
questions.hint: From the hip bone point to the pubic bone bump.

questions.question: Identify the CORRECT statement regarding the inguinal canal walls:

options.text: The anterior wall is formed mainly by the transversalis fascia
The roof is formed by the arching fibers of internal oblique
The posterior wall is formed mainly by the external oblique aponeurosis
The floor is formed by the rectus sheath

questions.explanation: Roof = Internal Oblique/Transversus. Anterior = External Oblique. Posterior = Transversalis fascia/Conjoint tendon. Floor = Inguinal ligament.
questions.hint: MALT: Muscles (Roof), Aponeurosis (Ant), Ligament (Floor), Transversalis (Post).

questions.question: A direct inguinal hernia passes lateral to the inferior epigastric artery.
questions.explanation: FALSE. A DIRECT hernia passes MEDIAL to the inferior epigastric artery (through Hesselbach's triangle). An INDIRECT hernia passes LATERAL to it (through the deep ring).
questions.hint: Direct goes directly through the wall; Indirect goes 'Into' the deep ring.

questions.question: Arrange the parts of the duodenum in order from proximal to distal:
questions.explanation: 1st (Superior) -> 2nd (Descending, receives bile/pancreatic ducts) -> 3rd (Horizontal) -> 4th (Ascending to DJ flexure).
questions.hint: It curves around the head of the pancreas.

questions.question: Where is the surface marking for the fundus of the gall-bladder?

options.text: Tip of the 9th costal cartilage at the lateral border of the rectus sheath

questions.explanation: The fundus of the gall-bladder lies at the tip of the 9th costal cartilage where the linea semilunaris (lateral rectus border) crosses the costal margin.
questions.hint: It's on the right side, where the rectus muscle meets the ribs.

questions.question: Which of the following are distinguishing features of the LARGE intestine? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The large intestine has Teniae coli (3 bands), Haustra (sacculations), and fatty tags (Appendices epiploicae). Valvulae conniventes are in the small bowel.
questions.hint: Look for features NOT found in the smooth small intestine.

questions.question: What is the name of the sphincter that controls the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the duodenum?
questions.explanation: The Sphincter of Oddi guards the hepatopancreatic ampulla (Ampulla of Vater) where the bile duct and main pancreatic duct enter the 2nd part of the duodenum.
questions.hint: Named after an Italian anatomist.

questions.question: Review the table describing Porto-Systemic Anastomoses. Which row correctly identifies the vessels involved at the lower oesophagus?

richContent.content:
SitePortal TributarySystemic Tributary
ALeft Gastric VeinAzygos Vein
BSuperior Rectal VeinInferior Rectal Vein
CPara-umbilical VeinsEpigastric Veins

questions.explanation: At the lower oesophagus, the Left Gastric vein (Portal) anastomoses with oesophageal branches of the Azygos vein (Systemic). Dilation here causes oesophageal varices.
questions.hint: This site is prone to bleeding varices in liver cirrhosis.

questions.question: The spleen is a retroperitoneal organ.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ, connected to the stomach (gastrosplenic ligament) and kidney (lienorenal ligament).
questions.hint: It has ligaments attaching it to other organs.

questions.question: Which artery runs in the free edge of the lesser omentum?
questions.explanation: The free edge of the lesser omentum (anterior to the epiploic foramen) contains the Portal Vein, Hepatic Artery, and Common Bile Duct.
questions.hint: It travels to the porta hepatis.

questions.question: The kidneys lie in the retroperitoneum. The ___BLANK___ kidney typically lies lower than the ___BLANK___ kidney.
questions.explanation: The right kidney is pushed down by the large liver, so it sits lower than the left kidney.
questions.hint: Think about the liver's position.

questions.question: Which of the following are posterior relations of the stomach (forming the 'stomach bed')? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The stomach bed consists of the Pancreas, Left Kidney, Left Adrenal, Spleen, Splenic Artery, Transverse Mesocolon, and Diaphragm. The Liver is anterior/superior.
questions.hint: Think about what lies directly behind the lesser sac.

questions.question: A patient presents with pain radiating from the loin to the groin. This is characteristic of:
questions.explanation: Ureteric colic typically presents with agonizing pain radiating from the loin to the groin as the stone moves down the ureter.
questions.hint: It involves the urinary tract.

questions.question: Match the part of the pancreas with its anatomical relation:

pairs.right: Within the curve of the duodenum
Anterior to the formation of the portal vein
Posterior to the Superior Mesenteric vessels

questions.explanation: The head is in the C-loop of the duodenum. The neck overlies the portal vein origin. The uncinate process tucks behind the SMA/SMV. The tail reaches the splenic hilum.
questions.hint: Trace the pancreas from right to left.

questions.question: Which of the following ligaments contains the splenic vessels?
questions.explanation: The lienorenal (splenorenal) ligament connects the kidney to the spleen and contains the splenic artery/vein and the tail of the pancreas. The gastrosplenic contains short gastric vessels.
questions.hint: It connects the Spleen (Lien) to the Kidney (Renal).

questions.question: The superior mesenteric artery arises from the aorta at which vertebral level?
questions.explanation: Coeliac trunk = T12/L1 border. Superior Mesenteric Artery = L1. Renal Arteries = L2. Inferior Mesenteric Artery = L3. Bifurcation = L4.
questions.hint: It is just below the Coeliac trunk.

questions.question: The jejunum has more arterial arcades and shorter vasa recta compared to the ileum.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The JEJUNUM has FEWER arcades and LONGER vasa recta. The ILEUM has MANY arcades and SHORTER vasa recta.
questions.hint: Jejunum = Simple vascular pattern. Ileum = Complex.

questions.question: Trace the flow of bile from the liver lobule to the duodenum:
questions.explanation: Bile flows from microscopic canaliculi -> hepatic ducts -> common hepatic duct -> (joined by cystic duct) -> common bile duct -> duodenum.
questions.hint: Start microscopic and move to macroscopic ducts.

questions.question: The appendix is supplied by the appendicular artery, which is a branch of the:
questions.explanation: The appendicular artery is a branch of the ileocolic artery (which comes from the SMA). It runs in the mesoappendix.
questions.hint: It comes from the artery supplying the ileum and caecum junction.

questions.question: Which of the following are boundaries of the epiploic foramen (of Winslow)? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Anterior: Portal vein, Hepatic artery, Bile duct

questions.explanation: The foramen of Winslow is bounded by the IVC (post), Free edge of lesser omentum (ant), Caudate lobe (sup), and Duodenum (inf).
questions.hint: Think of the structures surrounding the opening into the lesser sac.

questions.question: What is the name of the venous structure formed by the union of the common iliac veins at L5?
questions.explanation: The IVC is formed by the right and left common iliac veins at L5, to the right of the midline.
questions.hint: It carries blood back to the heart from the lower body.

questions.question: The lymphatic drainage of the testes is to which lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: The testes develop high in the abdomen and descend, dragging their blood/lymph supply with them. Thus, they drain to the para-aortic nodes, NOT the inguinal nodes (which drain the scrotum).
questions.hint: Follow the testicular artery back to its origin.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles is a powerful flexor of the thigh and inserts into the lesser trochanter?
questions.explanation: Psoas major and Iliacus fuse to form the Iliopsoas, which passes under the inguinal ligament to insert on the lesser trochanter. It is the primary hip flexor.
questions.hint: It originates from the lumbar spine and iliac fossa.

questions.question: The suprarenal (adrenal) glands are enclosed within the renal fascia.
questions.explanation: The adrenal glands lie on the upper pole of the kidneys and are enclosed within the same compartment of renal fascia (Gerota's fascia).
questions.hint: They are 'supra-renal' and sit like a cap.

questions.question: The abdominal aorta bifurcates into the common iliac arteries at the level of the ___BLANK___ vertebra.
questions.explanation: The abdominal aorta bifurcates at L4. (The IVC forms at L5).
questions.hint: One level below the umbilicus (L3).

questions.question: Which structure prevents the ascent of the kidney (horseshoe kidney) in the abdomen?
questions.explanation: A horseshoe kidney (fused lower poles) gets trapped under the Inferior Mesenteric Artery (IMA) during its ascent.
questions.hint: It is the lowest unpaired branch of the abdominal aorta.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the cisterna chyli?

options.text: To drain venous blood from the legs
To collect lymph from the abdomen and lower limbs

questions.explanation: The cisterna chyli is a dilated lymphatic sac at L1/L2 that receives lymph from the intestinal and lumbar trunks before continuing as the thoracic duct.
questions.hint: It is the start of the thoracic duct.
